metadata.title: Influence of different types of nano-SiO2 particles on properties of high-performance concrete

sections.text:

Influence of different types of nano-SiO2 particles on properties of high-performance concrete

Alireza Khaloo, Mohammad Hossein Mobini ⇑, Payam Hosseini Department of Civil Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran
h i g h l i g h t s
Effect of different sizes of nano-SiO2 particles on HPC properties was investigated. By decreasing w/b ratio, coarser nano-SiO2 improved mechanical properties of HPC more than finer type. Finer nano-SiO2 showed higher pozzolanic activity than coarser nanoparticles. Probability of nano-SiO2 agglomeration was increased by using finer type. Coarser type of nano-SiO2 led to a finer pore structure compared to finer particles.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 2 November 2014 Received in revised form 23 February 2016 Accepted 8 March 2016
Keywords: High-performance concrete Nano-SiO2 particles Specific surface area Mechanical properties Non-destructive testing Electrical resistivity Microstructural investigations
a b s t r a c t
The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of applying low replacement ratios (0.75% and 1.50% of the binder weight) of nano-SiO2 particles with different specific surface areas (200 and 380 m2/g) on the properties of high-performance concrete (HPC). Mechanical (compressive and splitting tensile strengths), electrical resistivity, non-destructive (ultrasonic pulse velocity), and microstructural (mercury intrusion porosimetry, X-ray diffraction, and scanning electron microscopy) tests were conducted to investigate the macroscopic and microscopic effects of nano-SiO2 particles on HPC characteristics. The results indicated that the performance of nano-SiO2 particles significantly depended on their specific surface areas and the water to binder (w/b) ratio of the mixtures. By decreasing the HPC w/b ratio from 0.35 to 0.25, nano-SiO2 particles with lower specific surface area performed better than finer one (higher specific surface area). Microstructural investigations demonstrated that the decrease in efficiency of nano-SiO2 particles with higher specific surface area at lower w/b ratio correlates to the formation of nanoparticles agglomerates, particularly at the higher replacement ratio of nanosilica (1.5%). However, the influence on the compressive and splitting tensile strengths and electrical resistivity varied due to differences in performance of nano-SiO2 particles affected the mechanical and durability properties.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, improving the durability of cement-based products has become a key factor to improve the lifespan of concrete structures [1]. Indeed, durability enhancement of cement-based materials can extend the service life of concrete structures, particularly infrastructures and special structures, such as sewage systems, highway bridges, tunnels, and marine structures, which are important for every society.
Increasing the service life of concrete structures can delay the demolition and reconstruction of these structures. As a result, in a specific period, less debris can be produced by demolition and
fewer construction materials will be consumed for reconstruction. In fact, less construction waste will be generated and fewer raw materials will be required for production of construction materials.
High-performance concrete (HPC) is designed with high workability, high strength, and high durability [2]. The design of HPC is based on selecting low water to binder ratios (usually between 0.25 and 0.35), limiting maximum aggregate size, and the application of highly reactive pozzolanic materials, such as blast furnace slag, silica fume, and fly ash [3,4].
Nanoparticles have been widely recognized as the most important products of nanotechnology [5]. These particles have significant effects on the properties of different products according to their fine dimensions, physical and chemical properties. Among the different nanoparticles available in the market, nano-SiO2 particles significantly affect the properties of cement-based composites
because of their high purity (greater than 99%), and high specific surface areas [6,7]. Numerous researchers have investigated the effects of nano-SiO2 particles on the performance of cement-based materials, such as cement paste, mortar, and concrete [5–9]. According to previous research [5–10], nano-SiO2 particles enhance the mechanical performance and durability properties of cement-based materials and thicken cementitious fresh mixtures. However, the application of large amounts of nano-SiO2 particles (more than 5% cement replacement) can lead to detrimental effects on the mechanical and durability properties of cement-based materials [11,12]. This can be attributed to the high specific surface areas of nano-SiO2 particles, increasing the probability of nanoparticle agglomeration and consequently causing poor dispersion of nano-SiO2 particles in the cement-based matrices [13,14]. The high specific surface areas of nano-SiO2 particles can affect the fresh properties of cement-based mixtures because of the absorption of water molecules at their surface [8,9]. Nano-SiO2 particles thicken fresh mixtures, increasing the probability of air bubbles entraining during mixture casting and inhibiting proper compaction of specimens [6,7,11]. Increasing the specific surface area of nano-SiO2 particles by decreasing their dimensions can intensify the agglomeration of these particles because of the increasing particle surface energy [12]. By increasing the specific surface area of the nano-SiO2 particles and/or the incremental addition of these nanoparticles, the dispersion of nano-SiO2 particles becomes more difficult [15,16]. Therefore, special dispersion methods, such as ultrasound mixing may be required, significantly increasing the fabrication costs of cement-based specimens [16,17].
To avoid the application of special mixing procedures and to develop HPC mixtures using conventional mixing methods, the utilization of low replacement ratios of nano-SiO2 particles (0.75% and 1.50%) was considered in this study. Furthermore, based on the high specific surface areas of nano-SiO2 particles (200 and 380 m2/g) utilized and low water to binder ratios (0.25, 0.30, and 0.35) of the concrete mixtures, it is reasonable to apply such low nanosilica dosages.
Because of the importance of HPC application for concrete infrastructures, nano-SiO2 particles can be utilized as a highly reactive pozzolanic material in the HPC matrix. However, there is limited published research on fabricating HPC by incorporating nanoSiO2 particles [18,19]. According to Baomin et al. [18], nano-SiO2 can develop the microstructure of HPC and consequently improve the freezing resistance of specimens. Pacheco-Torgal et al. [19] stated that further investigations are required to discover which nanoparticles are the most effective for developing high durability mixtures, such as HPC.
Considering the previously presented information related to the importance of HPC production and the use of nano-SiO2 particles in concrete, the aim of this study is to assess the feasibility of the application of low replacement ratios of nano-SiO2 particles (0.75% and 1.50%) with different specific surface areas (200 and 380 m2/g) in the production of HPC mixtures. To determine the properties of HPC incorporating nano-SiO2 particles, different tests were conducted. The compressive and splitting tensile strengths were obtained to evaluate the mechanical performance of the nano-reinforced HPC specimens. To investigate the effects of nano-SiO2 particles on the pore structure of the HPC matrices and their conductivity, mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP) and electrical resistivity tests, respectively, were performed. In addition, to develop a regression model for predicting compressive strength with a non-destructive test, the ultrasonic pulse velocity (UPV) through the concrete specimens was determined. X-ray diffraction (XRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) tests were conducted on high-performance cement paste and concrete fragments to explain the primary behaviors of nano-SiO2 particles that affect the mechanical and durability properties of the HPC specimens.
2. Experimental plan
2.1. Materials
The binder included cement and nano-SiO2 particles (pyrogenic type) with different specific surface areas. The cement used was Type II Portland cement that meets the requirements of ASTM C 150 [20].
The pyrogenic nanosilicas are generally produced through reaction of silicon tetrachloride, hydrogen and oxygen in high temperature furnaces [21–23]. They can be produced with different specific surface areas ranging from about 50 m2/g to 400 m2/g [23]. In the production process of these materials, the particles fuse together and form primary aggregates with dimensions up to a hundred nanometers. The primary aggregates also bind together and form agglomerates up to about a few hundred micrometers in length [21–24]. Therefore, the main product has particles with dimensions of micrometers containing millions of SiO2 nanoparticles. The physical and chemical properties of the cement and pyrogenic nanosilicas are listed in Tables 1 and 2, respectively.
A polycarboxylate-based superplasticizer (with 40 ± 1% solid content, pH of 7 ± 1, and specific gravity of 1.12 ± 0.05 at 20.4 C) was employed to aid the dispersion of the nanoparticles and achieve good flowability in the HPC mixtures. Coarse aggregate with a maximum size of 19 mm, a specific gravity of 2.73, and water absorption of 1.61% was used. The fine aggregate was natural river sand with a specific gravity of 2.63, absorption of 2.59%, and fineness modulus of 3.17. Both the coarse and fine aggregates met the requirements of ASTM C 33 [25]. Potable water was used for the preparation of the HPC mixtures.
2.2. Mixing and testing procedures
The binder content (550 kg/m3) was kept constant for all of the HPC mixtures. In addition, the ratio of coarse aggregate to fine aggregate was maintained at 1.5. Three water to binder ratios (0.25, 0.30, and 0.35) were selected for use in fabricating the HPC mixtures. Portland cement was partially replaced with pyrogenic nanosilicas at the two addition ratios of 0.75% and 1.50% by weight. To achieve a constant slump level (26 ± 1 cm), a superplasticizer was used at different dosages for all mixtures. Table 3 presents the mix proportions of the HPC mixtures.
To fabricate homogenous and uniform HPC mixtures, the following procedure was employed:
- Coarse and fine aggregates in a saturated surface dry (SSD) condition were added to the pan type mixer and were mixed together for one min. - Cement was added to the mixer and the ingredients were mixed together for 30 s. - Slurry of pyrogenic nanosilica (if applicable) was added into the mixer and the mixture was mixed for approximately two min. - The remaining mixing water (in the mixtures containing nanosilica) or the entire quantity of water (in the control mixtures) incorporated with the superplasticizer were added to the mixer and mixing was continued for four min.
To improve the performance of pyrogenic nanosilicas in the HPC matrix, a predispersion method was used. At each w/b ratio, nanosilica slurry, in the form of a colloidal dispersion with 10% solid content, was prepared by mechanical mixing using a high-shear mixer rotating at 1500 rpm. The water required for preparing the nanosilica slurry was a portion of the mixing water. The main reason for predispersion was efficient de-agglomeration of the nano-SiO2 particles before using them to fabricate HPC mixtures.
Immediately after mixing, a portion of the fresh mixture was used for measuring slump and slump flow of the fresh HPC mixtures according to ASTM C 143 [26] and ASTM C 1611 [27], respectively. The remaining fresh mixture was then poured into oiled molds to form 100 mm cubes for compressive strength and electrical resistivity tests and ultrasonic pulse velocity measurement. Cylinders of

The compressive and splitting tensile strengths were performed according to BS 1881-116 [28] and ASTM C 496 [29], respectively. The ultrasonic pulse velocity (UPV) measurement test was conducted on cubic specimens in accordance with ASTM C 597 [30]. The UPV measurement was conducted to develop a regression function for predicting compressive strength from the UPV test results.
Electrical resistivity testing was conducted on two cubic specimens for each HPC mixture at specified curing periods. The electrical resistivity of the cubes was measured based on AC impedance spectrometry using a resistance-meter [31]. The resistivity was calculated according to Eq. (1).

where q is the electrical resistivity (KX cm), A is the area (cm2) of the specimen in contact with electrodes, R is the resistance (KX), and L is the length of specimen in the direction of the current (cm).
After performing the splitting tensile strength test on the concrete specimens at 28 days, the crushed fragments from the fractured surfaces were selected and placed into an acetone tank for 48 h to stop hydration. They were then dried in an oven at 50 C for 24 h. Next, they were removed from the oven and were cooled in a desiccator until microstructural tests were performed [9]. It should be noted that three mixtures with a w/b ratio of 0.30 were selected for the microstructural investigations. These mixtures included the control HPC (without nano-SiO2 particles) and the HPCs incorporating 1.5% nano-SiO2 particles with specific surface areas of 200 and 380 m2/g (NS200 and NS380, respectively). The w/b ratio of 0.30 was the average of the w/b ratios used in this study (0.25, 0.30, and 0.35) and 1.5% NS200 caused the highest compressive and splitting tensile strengths at this w/b ratio (based on the mechanical test results presented in later sections). The w/b ratio of 0.30 and NS200 with replacement percentage of 1.5% were thus selected for further investigation. However, to conduct a comparison between the microstructural performances of pyrogenic nanosilicas with different specific surface areas, specimens incorporating NS380 at an identical dosage as NS200 (1.5%), at w/b ratio of 0.30, were also selected.
To examine the microstructure of the HPC mixtures, some of the fragments obtained from the splitting tensile strength test at 28 days of curing, prepared according to the previously mentioned instructions for microstructural tests, were coated with gold for the SEM test. The Philips XL 30 SEM was used for morphological investigations of the HPC matrix. The pore structures of the selected HPC specimens were studied by MIP using a PASCAL 440 series instrument. MIP is based on the principle that a non-wetting liquid (one with a contact angle with the solid greater than 90 ) will only intrude into a porous medium under pressure. The relationship between the applied pressure and the pore diameter (with the assumption of cylindrical shape) is described by the Washburn equation [32] as follows (Eq. (2)):
D ¼ 4c cos h P

where D is the pore diameter (m), c is the surface tension of the liquid (in this case, mercury) (N/m), h is the contact angle between liquid (mercury) and solid ( ), and P is the applied pressure (N/m2). The surface tension of mercury was taken as 0.485 N/m, and the contact angle between mercury and the pore wall was 140 . The maximum applied pressure was 280 MPa, corresponding to a minimum pore size of 5 nm.
To investigate the formed phase composition in the HPC matrices, the XRD test was conducted on the representative cement pastes for the three HPC mixtures at 3 (as a representative of early age curing up to 7 days) and 28 days of curing (as a representative of short-term curing up to 91 days). The preparation of high-performance cement paste fragments for XRD was based on that of the HPC microstructural test previously specified. The XRD test was applied on the paste samples instead of the concrete fragments to evaluate exactly the phase composition in the concrete matrix paste where the chemical reactions of cementitious materials occurred. The XRD measurements were performed in the scanning range of 2h from 10 to 60 , with a step size of 0.03 and scan speed of 2 /min.

sections.heading: 3.1. Slump flow
sections.text: According to Table 3, at each w/b ratio, the addition of nanoSiO2 particles to the HPC increases its content reduced mixture flow. At a specified w/b ratio, by increasing the specific surface area of nano-SiO2 particles the flow diameter of the HPC mixture was decreased. These observations can be related to the high specific surface area of the nano-SiO2 particles that cause cohesive forces between nanoparticles and consequently large SiO2-agglomerates to be formed. As a result, the agglomerates of nano-SiO2 particles possess a high water adsorption and significant water retention capacity because of their high specific surface area and high nano-scale porosity [13,33]. The formation of a denser packing of solid particles in the mixtures containing nanosilica is another reason for the substantial increase in yield stress and viscosity of cement-based materials [8,33]. Consequently, higher superplasticizer dosages are required to maintain slump and inhibit flow reduction in HPC mixtures by increasing replacement ratios and specific surface areas of nano-SiO2 particles.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Compressive strength
sections.text:
Figs. 1–3 show the results of the compressive strength tests on the HPC mixtures with w/b ratios of 0.35, 0.30, and 0.25, respectively.
These results indicate that the application of nano-SiO2 particles increased the compressive strength of HPC mixtures compared with the control mixture (without nanosilica). However, this result was not valid for all replacement ratios and specific surface areas of nano-SiO2 particles, and this issue will be discussed in more details. Additional points concerning the performance of nano-SiO2 particles in the matrix of cement-based materials must be discussed.
By incorporating nanosilica into cement-based mixtures, these particles demonstrate fourfold performance [12,15]. Among these improvements, possessing high pozzolanic activity is considered the most important. Nano-SiO2 particles interact with water molecules in the pore solution and produce silanol groups (Si–OH) [34]. Silanol groups then react with Ca2+ ions released from Ca(OH)2 crystals in the pore solution and produce C-S-H gel [7,35].
Pyrogenic nanosilicas have high specific surface areas compared with conventional pozzolanic materials, such as fly ash; their surfaces are very active and accordingly these nanoparticles possess intensive pozzolanic activity in cementitious environments. Nanosilica demonstrates other improvements in addition to pozzolanic activity. These nanoparticles can act as a nucleus in the C-S-H gel structure to accelerate C-S-H formation and tightly bond with its particles [12,15,36–38]. In addition, the crystallization of unfavorable crystals (Ca(OH)2 and ettringite) will be controlled by restricting the growth of these crystals because of the existence of large numbers of nanoparticles between hydration products and their confinement role [12,15]. Finally, nano-SiO2 particles can fill micro- and nano-metric pores in the microstructure, particularly in the interfacial transition zone (ITZ) between the cement paste and aggregates. This contributes to the development of a denser ITZ and an increase in its strength [12,15].
According to Fig. 1, at w/b = 0.35, the higher percentage (1.5%) of different types of pyrogenic nanosilica (NS200 and NS380) performed better in increasing compressive strength. Additionally, as observed in Fig. 1, at the higher replacement ratio (1.5%), the
Fig. 1. Compressive strength of HPC
coarser type of pyrogenic nanosilica (NS200) up to 91 curing age and at the lower replacement ratio (0.75%), the finer type of pyrogenic nanosilica (NS380) up to 28 days of curing were more effective in improving HPC’s compressive strength. At the higher percentage of nano-SiO2 particles (1.5%), the probability of nanoparticles agglomeration is increased and this issue intensifies by raising specific surface area of nano-SiO2 particles [12,14,21,39] (see Section 3.4.3). As a result, efficiency of nanoparticles with higher specific surface area might be lower than that of coarser one at higher replacement ratios (e.g. 1.5%). In contrast, as finer type of pyrogenic nanosilica has higher pozzolanic activity than coarser one, by incorporating lower amount of finer nanosilica (e.g. 0.75%), the effectiveness of it will be improved owing to lower probability of nanoparticles agglomeration at low replacement ratios of nanosilica.
The highest compressive strength at different curing periods was achieved at the 1.5% NS200 replacement ratio. The compressive strength of the HPC mixture was increased by 21.5%, 25%, 12%, and 11% at 3, 7, 28, and 91 days of curing, respectively, with the addition of the 1.5% coarser nanosilica (NS200).
The compressive strength of the HPC mixtures containing nano-SiO2 particles with different specific surface areas (NS200 and NS380) was higher than that of control mixture at both 0.75% and 1.5% replacement dosages up to seven days of curing, which can be related to the higher pozzolanic activity of nanoSiO2 particles at early ages [9,15,21] (see Section 3.4.2). At later ages (28 and 91 days), the compressive strength enhancement of the control mixture was more pronounced. One reason might be the higher consumption of nano-SiO2 particles at early ages because of the higher activity of nanoparticles at early curing times. Therefore, fewer nano-SiO2 particles may be accessible for pozzolanic activity at later ages (see Section 3.4.2). This trend has been observed in other studies [40,41].
As observed in Fig. 2, at w/b = 0.30, pyrogenic nanosilica with lower specific surface area (NS200) caused more improvement in compressive strength compared to finer type (NS380). The lower percentage of NS200 (0.75%) performed better than NS380 at the different replacement ratios (0.75% and 1.5%). Furthermore, for pyrogenic nanosilica with lower specific surface area (200 m2/g), higher replacement ratio (1.5%) and for finer type (380 m2/g), a smaller percentage (0.75%) demonstrated better performance.

The highest compressive strength at different curing periods was reached with the replacement of 1.5% NS200. Replacement of 1.5% NS200 caused 15%, 5%, 8%, and 4% improvement in compressive strength of control mixture at 3, 7, 28, and 91 days of curing, respectively.
Similar to w/b = 0.35, higher percentages of nano-SiO2 particles were required to improve compressive strength at w/b = 0.30; however, this could be observed only in the HPC mixtures incorporating NS200 and the opposite trend was observed for NS380. This can be related to the higher probability of agglomeration of finer nanoparticles even at low replacement ratios which might be attributed to their high surface activities, which reduces the efficiency of the fourfold performance of nano-SiO2 particles in the cementitious matrix [12,14,21,39] (see Section 3.4.3). However, agglomeration of nano-SiO2 particles intensifies at lower w/b ratio where dispersion of nano-particles during mixing procedure is
more difficult and less efficient when mixing energy generated by mixer is nearly similar for producing HPC mixtures with different w/b ratios. In other words, the efficiency of a mixer with specific power to disperse nano-particles aptly will reduce during mixing time by decreasing w/b ratio due to increasing viscosity of fresh mixture incorporating nano-SiO2 particles [8], and this issue can heighten the probability of nanoparticles agglomerates formation.
Based on Fig. 2, the control mixture had higher compressive strength than mixtures containing different percentages of finer pyrogenic nanosilica (NS380). Although no specific method for better dispersion of nano-SiO2 particles in the matrix of fresh concrete mixtures was used in this study, the application of costly methods such as ultrasound mixing, would produce well-dispersed nanoparticles in the microstructure [17]. Therefore, improvement in the performance of nano-SiO2 particles could be achieved with
specific mixing methods not used in the current study for simplicity and cost minimization of the nano-reinforced HPC fabrication.
Based on Fig. 3, in general, coarser pyrogenic nanosilica (NS200) was more efficient in improving compressive strength. For mixtures incorporating NS200, a higher compressive strength was achieved at lower replacement ratio (0.75%).
The replacement of 0.75% NS200 improved compressive strength by 1%, 6%, 2%, and 1% at 3, 7, 28, and 91 days of curing, respectively. The improvement in compressive strength was negligible because of lowering trend of mixer’s effectiveness in dispersing nano-SiO2 particles during mixing procedure by decreasing w/b ratio.
In addition, the lower percentage of finer pyrogenic nanosilica (NS380) performed better at early ages (3 and 7 days of curing) than at later ages (28 and 91 days of curing). In this regard, the smaller percentages of nanosilica may be better dispersed in the matrix [6,12], because of smaller quantities of single nanoparticles that can gather and form large agglomerates. As a result, the smaller replacement ratio of nanoparticles was more efficient, particularly at early ages, because of their high pozzolanic activity (see Section 3.4.2).
At higher w/b ratios (particularly w/b = 0.35), larger quantities of pyrogenic nanosilicas had more influence on the improvement of compressive strength because more nano-SiO2 particles are required to make the matrix and ITZ denser, which have greater porosity at higher w/b ratios [2].
However, by decreasing the w/b ratio, the lower percentage (0.75%) of nanosilica showed better performance than the larger replacement. This can be related to the degree of decreasing hydration by reducing the w/b ratio [42]. When the w/b ratio is decreased, the production rate of Ca(OH)2 crystals is reduced. Accordingly, at a lower w/b ratio and at s specific curing period, a smaller quantity of Ca(OH)2 is available to react with the nanoSiO2 particles. Consequently, the pozzolanic activity of nano-SiO2 particles in cementitious environments is reduced and the effects of nanoparticle agglomerates will be more pronounced. Decreasing the dimensions of the nano-SiO2 particles increases the probability of the formation of large SiO2-agglomerates. Therefore, at lower w/ b ratio, the coarser pyrogenic nanosilica showed more pronounced performance than finer one.
As numerous previous studies have shown, the relationship between the compressive strength and UPV can be expressed by an exponential function [43]. Fig. 4 illustrates the exponential relationship between the compressive strength and UPV values for the current study. As observed in Eq. (3), R-square of the exponential model is 0.8972, which indicates a good correlation between the UPV and compressive strength results in this research. Therefore, the proposed model can be used to predict the compressive strength of HPC mixtures incorporating nano-SiO2 particles, using UPV measurements.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Splitting tensile strength
sections.text:
The results of the splitting tensile strength test are shown in Figs. 5–7. According to the obtained results, the splitting tensile strength measurements did not demonstrate trends similar to the compressive strength test results. However, in general, coarser pyrogenic nanosilica (NS200) was more effective than finer one (NS380) at different w/b ratios. In addition, a smaller percentage (0.75%) of nanosilica with higher specific surface area (NS380) performed better than the larger replacement (1.5%).
Similar to the results of compressive strength test (Section 3.2.1), at middle curing ages (28 and 91 days) the control mixture had higher splitting tensile strength than the HPC mixtures containing NS380 at w/b ratio of 0.25. As discussed in Section 3.2.1, this can be explained by the higher probability of agglomerates formation in the matrix incorporating pyrogenic nanosilica with higher specific surface area (NS380).
Based on the results (Figs. 5–7), the mixtures with coarser pyrogenic nanosilica (NS200) had higher splitting tensile strength than the control mixture and mixtures containing finer nanosilica (NS380). This observation could be connected with the lower probability of agglomerates formation in the presence of pyrogenic nanosilica with lower specific surface area. This increases their influence on cement paste matrix property improvements and the ITZ between the paste and aggregates.
Moreover, as the bonding improvement between paste and aggregates is a crucial factor in increasing concrete tensile strength [39], ITZ properties have more influence on tensile strength than on compressive strength. Accordingly, higher splitting tensile strength of mixtures containing NS200 than mixtures with NS380 could be related to better performance of coarser pyrogenic nanosilica in the ITZs (developing more compacted and homogeneous microstructure as discussed in Section 3.4.3).
The addition of 1.5% NS200 increased the splitting tensile strength at w/b ratios of 0.35 and 0.30 by 22%, 9%, 12%, and 9%, 10%, 10%, 10%, and 13% at 3, 7, 28, and 91 days of curing, respectively, compared to the control specimens. At w/b of 0.25, the 1.5% NS200 replacement improved the splitting tensile strength by 9%, 11%, and 4.5% at 3, 7, and 28 days of curing, respectively. However, at 91 days of curing there was a 4% reduction in splitting tensile strength.
Because an increase in particle packing and a reduction of unfavorable crystals (e.g., Ca(OH)2 and ettringite) dimensions have direct effects on improving ITZ strength [2], the fourfold performance of well-dispersed nano-SiO2 particles can develop ITZ and consequently significantly increase the splitting tensile strength in comparison with the compressive strength. The denser ITZ did not necessarily result in the highest compressive strength but the improvement of the ITZ can affect tensile strength and even durability [44,45]. However, ITZ properties can have a greater effect on compressive strength at lower w/b ratios, particularly below 0.30 [2].
It is interesting to note that, whereas nano-SiO2 particles develop the tensile strength of HPC mixtures by strengthening the ITZ, the improvement in the compressive strength of concrete mixtures with low w/b ratios (such as HPC) incorporating nanoSiO2 particles can be achieved by increasing the strength of the ITZ and cement paste simultaneously.

sections.heading: 3.3. Electrical resistivity
sections.text:
According to Fig. 8, the addition of pyrogenic nanosilica with different specific surface areas increased the electrical resistivity of the HPC mixtures at different w/b ratios and curing periods compared to the control mixtures. The increase in resistivity of the HPC mixtures in the presence of nano-SiO2 particles can be connected with the refinement of the pore structure and decreasing conductivity of the pore solution [39].
When nano-SiO2 particles are added to the cementitious mixture, fourfold performance of these particles cause microstructural improvements; a denser matrix develops by decreasing the pore dimensions and their connectivity [10,39]. The electrical resistivity of concrete also depends on the pore solution chemistry and the chemical binding of various ions in the pore solution, whereas these phenomena do not affect the strength [39,46,47]. As previously mentioned, pyrogenic nanosilicas demonstrated superior
pozzolanic performance and accelerated the cement hydration reaction (see Section 3.4.2). By incorporating pyrogenic nanosilicas, a faster consumption rate of Ca(OH)2 crystals (resulting in the rapid reduction of OH- concentration) because of the pozzolanic reaction and an increase in the binding of different ions, such as Na+ and K+, by reaction products from hydration acceleration, occur in the pore solution [39,46,47]. As a result, by decreasing ionic concentration (particularly OH ) in the pore solution, the electrical resistivity of the cementitious matrix is increased substantially in the presence of nano-SiO2 particles [46,47].
As depicted in Fig. 8, the higher replacement (1.5%) of different pyrogenic nanosilicas (NS200 and NS380) increased electrical
resistivity more than smaller addition (0.75%). This can be attributed to the increasing pozzolanic reaction rate and the hydration reaction intensity resulting from the increasing quantity of nanosilica [12]. At higher w/b ratios (0.35 and 0.30), finer pyrogenic nanosilica (NS380) performed better than coarser one (NS200), whereas NS200 was more effective at the w/b ratio of 0.25. This may be due to the higher probability of nanoparticles agglomerates formation at lower w/b ratios, which is more pronounced for finer pyrogenic nanosilica. At low w/b ratios (e.g., 0.25), the HPC exhibited higher viscosity (see Section 3.1), which makes mixing and dispersing nano-SiO2 particles in the fresh mixture more difficult. As previously discussed and can be observed in
the SEM test results (Section 3.4.3), finer pyrogenic nanosilica (NS380) exhibited larger agglomerates because of its higher active surfaces compared to coarser type (NS200). Therefore, larger agglomerates may be anticipated in the HPC mixture containing finer nanosilica at the low w/b ratio of 0.25 and this can adversely affect mechanical and durability performance of the concrete mixtures.
The application of higher percentage (1.5%) of finer pyrogenic nanosilica (NS380) may result in increasing the probability of
nanoparticles agglomeration as indicated in Section 3.2.1. However, according to the XRD test results (Section 3.4.2), pyrogenic nanosilica with larger specific surface area (NS380) exhibited higher pozzolanic activity than coarser one (NS200), which is a key factor in decreasing OH ionic concentration in the pore solution. The MIP test results (Section 3.4.1) showed higher average pore diameter and apparent total porosity in the matrix of the HPC containing NS380 as compared with the mixture incorporating NS200. As a result, the pore structure of the HPC mixtures with
NS380 was more interconnected than that of the mixture containing NS200, which can decrease the electrical resistivity of the matrix. Therefore, based on increasing electrical resistivity in the presence of higher percentage (1.5%) of NS380 at w/b ratios of 0.35 and 0.30, it can be concluded that high surface activity of NS380 performed more effectively in increasing the electrical resistivity of the HPC matrix compared to larger agglomerates of its particles which can adversely affect electrical resistivity.
According to ACI 222R-01 [48], the corrosion rate of steel reinforcement is low when the resistivity of concrete exceeds 20 kX cm. Accordingly, as can be observed in Fig. 8, at w/b = 0.35, HPC mixtures containing different types and percentages of pyrogenic nanosilica exhibited a low corrosion rate at 91 days of curing, whereas at w/b = 0.30 this trend extended to 28 days of curing. At w/b ratio of 0.25, the HPC mixtures with nano-SiO2 particles can be classified as concrete with low corrosion rate, even at seven days of curing.

sections.heading: 3.4.1. Mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP)
sections.text:
Fig. 9 shows the pore size distributions of the HPC mixtures with and without 1.5% nano-SiO2 particles, at w/b ratio of 0.30. The apparent total porosity and average pore diameter for each mentioned HPC mixture are presented in Table 4.
As observed from Fig. 9, the pore distributions of the HPC mixtures containing pyrogenic nanosilica with different specific surface areas were finer than that of control HPC mixture. The main reason could be attributed to the fourfold performance of nanosilica in the HPC matrix as described in Section 3.2.1. However, as shown in Fig. 9, the mixture incorporating 1.5% NS380 had greater porosity between approximately 0.6 lm and 7 lm compared to the control mixture because of large nanoparticles agglomerates in the matrix, which introduces porous aggregates into the microstructure [13] (see Section 3.4.3). Nanosilica agglomerates introduce more porosity to the mixture and cause connectivity between existing voids in the matrix through their porosities [7,13], which can form a coarser pore structure.
According to the results presented in Table 4, total porosity of the control mixture decreased by 16% and 9% with the additions of 1.5% NS200 and NS380, respectively. The average pore diameter
of the HPC matrix was reduced from 37.3 nm (for the control mixture) to 29.5 nm and 33.2 nm for the HPC mixtures containing 1.5% NS200 and NS380, respectively. As mentioned in Section 3.3, nanoSiO2 particles caused pore structure refinement; however, this trend was more significant in the HPC mixture with 1.5% NS200 than in the mixture incorporating 1.5% NS380 (at w/b ratio of 0.30), which can be related to the existence of more agglomerates in the matrix of the HPC containing finer pyrogenic nanosilica as described previously in this section.

sections.heading: 3.4.2. X-ray diffraction (XRD)
sections.text:
Figs. 10 and 11 illustrate the XRD patterns of cement pastes with and without nano-SiO2 particles at 3 and 28 days of curing, respectively. The main peaks observed were Ca(OH)2 (2h deg. 18.1, 28.7, 34.1, 47.1, and 50.8), C3S (2h deg. 29.3, 32.1, 32.5, and 34.4), C2S (2h deg. 32.1, 34.4, and 41.2), and quartz (2h deg. 20.8, 26.6, 36.5, 39.4, 42.4, 45.7, 50.1, and 54.8) [49,50].
As observed in Figs. 10 and 11, by the addition of different pyrogenic nanosilicas, Ca(OH)2, C3S (alite), and C2S (belite) peaks were reduced at 3 and 28 days of curing. The decreasing Ca(OH)2 peaks represent pozzolanic activity, and the reduction of alite and belite peaks indicate acceleration of cement hydration. Based on the XRD test results, finer pyrogenic nanosilica (NS380) exhibited more intense pozzolanic reaction and hydration acceleration than coarser type (NS200). This finding is consistent with the Bagheri et al. study [21], which indicated higher pozzolanic performance and increasing hydration promotion in the presence of finer nanoSiO2. They concluded that the initial size of the nano-SiO2 agglomerates did not influence the pozzolanic activity of the nano-SiO2 particles [21]. A large quantity of nano-SiO2 particles existing on the surface of agglomerates can react quickly in the microstructure; however, the efficiency of their performance decreases compared to when they are dispersed uniformly in the matrix.
As depicted in Figs. 10 and 11, both NS200 and NS380 exhibited better performance (pozzolanic activity and hydration accelerating) at early age (three days) than at middle age (28 days) owing to their high surface energy and numerous unsaturated bonds on their surfaces that cause rapid activity for nano-SiO2 particles [9,15,21,34].

sections.heading: 3.4.3. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM)
sections.text:
Figs. 12–17 represent the morphological characteristics of the HPC microstructure with and without nano-SiO2 particles. As observed in Fig. 12, the presence of unfavorable crystals, such as Ca(OH)2 and needle-like ettringite, and C-S-H gel are noticeable
in the microstructure of the control HPC mixture. In addition, some pores and microcracks exist in the matrix and the microstructure was not well compacted.
By incorporating nano-SiO2 particles into the HPC mixtures, the amount of unfavorable crystals were significantly decreased (Figs. 13 and 14). As Figs. 13 and 14 depict, a greater volume of C-S-H gel is noticed and the microstructures of the HPC mixtures
are more compacted compared to the control HPC matrix. As previously discussed, nano-SiO2 particles show fourfold performance in the cementitious matrices and therefore develop a denser and more compacted microstructure. This can be observed in the microstructure of the HPC mixtures containing NS200 and NS380, but there are some differences between them (Figs. 13 and 14).
As stated in earlier sections, nano-SiO2 particles with high specific surface area (e.g., NS380) exhibit a higher probability of forming nanoparticle agglomerates than coarser one (e.g., NS200); therefore the efficiency of coarser nanosilica can be greater than finer type. Figs. 15–17 illustrate the severity of nano-SiO2 particle agglomeration in the matrix of the HPC mixtures. According to Figs. 15 and 16, for the HPC mixture with NS380, the volume and dimensions of the agglomerates in air voids were significantly larger than agglomerates in the pores of the HPC containing NS200. Based on Fig. 17, nano-SiO2 agglomerates existed in the bulk volume of the matrix between the hydration products, which indicates the intense presence of agglomerates in the microstructure of the HPC containing finer nanosilica (NS380). The presence of nano-SiO2 agglomerates in the pores of the matrix can be related to agglomerate formation in the pore solution as discussed by Bagheri et al. [21]. However, due to the nature of pyrogenic nanosilicas one could expect some agglomerates in the matrix in spite of applying different pre-dispersion methods such as ultrasound or high-shear mixing. Nevertheless, the microstructure of the HPC mixture containing NS200 was more compacted than the mixture with NS380, which can result in a high strength matrix.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Based on the results obtained from this study, the following conclusions were drawn:
The addition of nano-SiO2 particles nanosilicas reduced the HPC flow spread. This trend was intensified by incorporating nanoSiO2 particles with higher specific surface area (380 m2/g in this research). The influence of nano-SiO2 particles on the mechanical properties of HPC mixtures was varied by changing its specific surface area. By decreasing the w/b ratio (from 0.35 to 0.25), the coarser pyrogenic nanosilica (NS200) at smaller percentage (0.75%) showed better performance in enhancing compressive strength than finer type (NS380). This result was more noticeable at the w/b ratio of 0.25. Moreover, at each w/b ratio (0.25, 0.30, and 0.35), the utilization of coarser pyrogenic nanosilica (NS200) at higher replacement ratio (1.5%) caused the highest splitting tensile strength among different HPC mixtures. In addition, at w/b ratio of 0.25, control mixture exhibited higher splitting tensile strength than HPC mixtures containing different percentages of NS380 at middle ages (28 and 91 days). Based on the experimental data, a two-parameter exponential function was proposed for estimating the compressive strength of the HPC mixtures containing nano-SiO2 particles using the UPV and compressive strength test results. Unlike mechanical strengths test results, the application of both coarse and fine pyrogenic nanosilicas at different replacement ratios (0.75% and 1.5%) increased the electrical resistivity of control HPC mixture at early and middle ages of curing (3, 7, 28, and 91 days) for w/b ratios between 0.25 and 0.35. Higher replacement ratio (1.5%) of nano-SiO2 particles caused greater increase in electrical resistivity. In addition, finer nanosilica (NS380) performed better than coarser one in increasing the electrical resistivity of control HPC mixture at w/b ratios of 0.35 and 0.30; however, coarser nanosilica (NS200) enhanced the electrical resistivity more than finer type at w/b ratio of 0.25. The MIP test results indicated that the coarser type of pyrogenic nanosilica (NS200) led to a finer pore structure compared to pyrogenic nanosilica with higher specific surface area (NS380).
Based on the XRD test results, finer pyrogenic nanosilica (NS380) exhibited higher pozzolanic activity and greater cement hydration acceleration than the coarser type (NS200). In addition, the presence of quartz peaks in the XRD diagrams of cement paste containing NS380 at both 3 and 28 days of curing indicates the existence of greater volumes of nano-SiO2 agglomerates in the matrix. However, by increasing the curing age, the intensity of the quartz peaks was reduced. The SEM investigations demonstrated that coarser pyrogenic nanosilica (NS200) performed better in the HPC matrix because a more compacted and denser microstructure developed. The finer type of nanosilica (NS380) caused the formation of more and larger nanoparticles agglomerates compared to the coarser one (NS200). To fulfill economic considerations, investigating the properties of HPC incorporating ternary cementitious blends of nanoSiO2 particles and other supplementary cementitious materials such as blast furnace slag, fly ash, and silica fume would be of great interest. In addition, utilization of high volume of waste pozzolanic materials such as fly ash to produce nanoreinforced HPC is of vital importance from environmental point of view.

metadata.abstractText: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of applying low replacement ratios (0.75% and 1.50% of the binder weight) of nano-SiO2 particles with different specific surface areas (200 and 380 m/g) on the properties of high-performance concrete (HPC). Mechanical (compressive and splitting tensile strengths), electrical resistivity, non-destructive (ultrasonic pulse velocity), and microstructural (mercury intrusion porosimetry, X-ray diffraction, and scanning electron microscopy) tests were conducted to investigate the macroscopic and microscopic effects of nano-SiO2 particles on HPC characteristics. The results indicated that the performance of nano-SiO2 particles significantly depended on their specific surface areas and the water to binder (w/b) ratio of the mixtures. By decreasing the HPC w/b ratio from 0.35 to 0.25, nano-SiO2 particles with lower specific surface area performed better than finer one (higher specific surface area). Microstructural investigations demonstrated that the decrease in efficiency of nano-SiO2 particles with higher specific surface area at lower w/b ratio correlates to the formation of nanoparticles agglomerates, particularly at the higher replacement ratio of nanosilica (1.5%). However, the influence on the compressive and splitting tensile strengths and electrical resistivity varied due to differences in performance of nano-SiO2 particles affected the mechanical and durability properties. 2016 Elsevier Ltd.
